ChrisL

Chris one of the happiest accidents that happened in Manhattan was when a building in the '30s they had to open a wall to make renovations and found a WPA mural, perfectly preserved. What some genius decided was to create a new wall in front of the mural. Its impressive.

My old high school, Brooklyn Tech. had a large central hall which was covered on all sides by a grand [WPA mural](http://web.archive.org/web/20100702071259/http:/www.bthsalum.org/mural.htm) done in 1934 by Maxwell B. Starr.

Even my town post office has a great WPA mural painted in the lobby. Many states list there WPA murals as this [WPA Art in Massachusetts site.](http://web.archive.org/web/20100702071259/http:/www.wpamurals.com/Massachu.html)

Here's the [WPA murals by US states](http://web.archive.org/web/20100702071259/http:/www.wpamurals.com/) link.

Yes, I'm old, but I'm back in style!

I see we have a visitor from the Ming dynasty :-)

ChrisL
Chris he will be fine as long as he leaves his horse and his sword outside.
[The Library of Congress](http://web.archive.org/web/20100702071259/http:/memory.loc.gov/ammem/wpaposters/wpahome.html) has a massive online collection of WPA posters.

As noted at the [H&FJ blog](http://web.archive.org/web/20100702071259/http:/www.typography.com/ask/showBlog.php?blogID=246), there's now a very nice [way in](http://web.archive.org/web/20100702071259/http:/www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/wpapos/search/?co=wpapos&sp=1&st=slideshow) to the LoC holdings that oldnick mentioned six years ago.
